verses.text: I was glad when they said to me, 'Let us go to the house of the Lord.'
verses.comment: Here, the psalmist expresses deep joy at the invitation to worship in God's house, highlighting the privilege and unity of corporate worship—a foretaste of the heavenly gathering (Heb. 12:22-24).

verses.text: Our feet are standing within your gates, O Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The psalmist rejoices at finally being in Jerusalem, the city chosen for God’s presence (Deut. 12:5), prefiguring the Church as the spiritual city where believers draw near to God (Rev. 21:2).

verses.text: Jerusalem, built as a city joined together as one,
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s unity points to God’s design for His people to be joined together in one faith and worship (Eph. 4:3-6), prefiguring the perfect unity of the Church as the body of Christ.

verses.text: to which the tribes go up—the tribes of the Lord—as a testimony for Israel, to praise the name of the Lord.
verses.comment: All the tribes gathering in Jerusalem (‘the tribes of the Lord’) reflect God’s desire for all His people to worship together in truth and unity. This anticipates the gathering of every nation into one spiritual family through Christ (Acts 2:5-11).

verses.text: For there, thrones for judgment were set, the thrones of the house of David.
verses.comment: Jerusalem was the center of both worship and royal authority. The mention of David’s thrones points to the promised eternal kingship fulfilled in Jesus, the son of David (Luke 1:32-33), who rules with justice.

verses.text: Pray for the peace of Jerusalem: 'May those who love you be secure.'
verses.comment: Praying for Jerusalem’s peace goes beyond earthly blessing—it also points toward seeking peace and security in God’s chosen people and His dwelling place, a call to spiritual unity (John 17:20-23).

verses.text: Peace be within your walls, and security within your citadels.
verses.comment: Peace and protection for Jerusalem symbolize the inner peace and stability received by those who dwell in God’s presence—a foreshadowing of Christ’s offer of true peace (John 14:27).

verses.text: For the sake of my brothers and my friends, I will say, 'Peace be within you.'
verses.comment: Peace is sought for the entire community, not just individual benefit, reflecting the biblical call to intercede for each other, just as Christ prays for His followers (Heb. 7:25).

verses.text: For the sake of the house of the Lord our God, I will seek your good.
verses.comment: The psalm ends with devotion to the house of the Lord—a concern for God’s dwelling and its welfare, which reflects the ideal of prioritizing God’s worship and presence, a theme later echoed in the New Testament community (Acts 2:46-47).
